testimony: Mr Chairman, perhaps it might be convenient to recall Mr Wasserman at this stage.  His application, you will recall is in bundle 2, from page 112 onwards Mr Chairman.
(continued)  Mr Wasserman, you gave evidence previously in these hearings, is that correct?
And you took the oath to speak the truth previously, do you consider yourself still bound to speak the truth in terms of the previous oath that you took?

Mr Wasserman we are not going to rehash or revisit the evidence which you already gave in regard to the political situation and political objectives.
	Can we go straight to the incident regarding Ndwandwe?

Now, you have heard the evidence of the previous witnesses.  Will you briefly tell the Committee where you came into it, and what your part was first in the abduction and through to the end of the incident where Ms Ndwandwe was eliminated and buried?
Well Mr Chairman, I accompanied all the names that had been mentioned so far to the house.
Mr Wasserman, can you just speak up a little bit please.

I accompanied the persons and personalities that had been mentioned by the previous applicants to this house at Onverwacht.
	Later, we all had our responsibilities from there, we knew what they were.  I then proceeded with the bakkie through Lavumisa border post.
Which border post is that, we have heard of ...
Oh, on the South African side it is called Culel, the Swazi side it is Lavumisa, it is the same post.
I am sorry, I don't know whether I am the only one that is confused, but I have heard of a border post Culel and the other one is Onverwacht.  Which of the two did you enter?
It is Culel, but it is also Lavumisa, it is the same place.
Well, let's just stick to what we know, Culel.
Yes Mr Chairman, but it becomes very confusing on the record, when suddenly one refers to different names of people and places where we know which ones we have been referring to so far.
If you could just stick to the names that we have been using so far.  Please continue.

All right Mr Chairman, so from there, I proceeded up towards Manzini where I waited on Culel/Manzini road.  Later on I met up with Du Preez.  At that point where we met, is where the two informers were handed their bakkie.
What were the two of you travelling in at that stage?
Mr Chairman, at that stage I was alone in the bakkie.
Du Preez was in the minibus.
It was actually a panel van Mr Chairman, but we will call it a kombi.  All right, and you say there you handed the bakkie to the two informers, and what did you do, get into the kombi with Du Preez?
We then proceeded into Manzini and took up a surveillance position.
Behind or in front of the bakkie?
In front of the bakkie, which was in the vicinity of the entrance to the George Hotel.
What time of the day was this approximately?
I would estimate it now between 17H00 and 18H00 Mr Chairman.
Between five o'clock and six o'clock in the afternoon, all right?
We were informed by radio that the subject, Ms Ndwandwe had arrived and had entered the bakkie.
They were in a position behind the bakkie.

Sorry to interrupt the course of things Mr Visser, but you said that you wouldn't want to lead all the evidence once again, in order to expedite matters, is there any reason why you are coming back to this?

Mr Chairman, yes, I certainly am not doing this because I think that I  have nothing else to do.  I am just wondering whether this witness shouldn't at least tell you what his participation was.
	Perhaps I can go a little quicker, thank you for the indication Mr Chairman.  Perhaps if I may then just lead you, is it true that at some stage, Ms Ndwandwe got into the bakkie with the two informers?
That the bakkie then left Manzini and travelled towards the Big Bend?
Did you follow them or did you go ahead of them?
Ahead, and Taylor with his vehicle and occupants followed from behind the bakkie?
Is it also correct that some distance away as Mr Forster had testified, the vehicles came to a standstill and Ndwandwe was transferred from the bakkie into the kombi?
From there, with which vehicle did you travel?
I was in the bakkie Mr Chairman, no, I was in the kombi, the kombi bus Mr Chairman.
In the kombi?  Mr Botha and Mr Forster said that it was raining that day, is that your recollection?

And that on the way to Hluti, the vehicles came to a standstill and Botha and Ndwandwe got onto the back of the bakkie, covered with a tarpaulin and where did you then, which vehicle did you then alight?
I then took charge and drove the 4 x 4, the bakkie.
You drove the bakkie and who was with you?
Du Preez.  The other two vehicles left and exited at Culel?
Where did you then go, did you go passed Hluti and where?
I proceeded to a point on the fence line, on the border fence line where Mr Botha and Ms Ndwandwe were handed over.
Did they climb through the fence?
And who was on the other side?
There was Mr Taylor and Mr Steyn, and Mr Forster.
All right, what did you then do, you and Du Preez I should ask?
The Culel border post was closed, so we continued along the southern road of Swaziland.
Did you go back to Manzini?
Did you stay over in Manzini that evening, that night?
We only got there in the early hours of the next morning, but we did stay over in Manzini, yes.

There seems to be a suggestion that there was a burglary in a house where Ms Ndwandwe was living and that money was taken.  If it is suggested that either you or Du Preez or you and Du Preez did that, what would you say about that?
I deny that emphatically Mr Chairman.
Did you know where she lived?
Mr Chairman, she had various houses, she was very difficult to find at any set stage.  I wouldn't have known exactly where she would have even kept that.
If you wanted to go and find her at her house, you say you wouldn't have known where to go?
Not instantly Mr Chairman, one would have to mount a little bit of an operation around it, but not instantly, she had various addresses.
Yes.  You exited the next day, is that correct from Swaziland?
I want to ask you, did you enter and exit Swaziland, you, yourself on valid passports and travel documents?
Mr Chairman, I had a false South African passport.
A false South African passport as well Mr Chairman.
And you entered and exited both ways, on the false passports?
What did you do after you had exited at Culel the next, I am sorry, where did you exit the next morning?
At Culel, and where did you then go?
We proceeded to the house at Onverwacht border post.
Yes, where you found Steyn and Botha and Forster and Ms Ndwandwe, is that correct?
Did you participate in her interrogation at all?
And thereafter, you left for a farm in the Elandskop area in Pietermaritzburg, is that correct?
With which vehicle did you travel?
And was Botha and Ndwandwe also in the kombi?
Was anybody talking to her, interrogating her during the trip from Swaziland to Pietermaritzburg?
Mr Botha was having discussions with her in the kombi.
Yes.  Did you listen to the contents of those discussions?
I was unable to listen due to the aboarding between the front and the back, I couldn't hear the conversation.
After arriving at the farm, at Pietermaritzburg, did you there participate in any interrogation of Ndwandwe?
I took part in some questioning of Ms Ndwandwe Mr Chairman.
Was she assaulted at any time during her interrogations where you were present?
No, she was not Mr Chairman.
All right.  Did you know what the decision was in her regard, what was going to happen to her?
I was aware of the situation in that regard Mr Chairman.
From the outset?  And eventually it transpired that she would not, she was not willing to cooperate with the police and certain orders were given?
As far as you are concerned, what were those orders?
I was asked by Mr Taylor, to eliminate Ms Ndwandwe.
Yes, would you just tell us what happened?
He told me that it was really now, Du Preez and I took her outside of the house, to where the grave had been dug previously.
By Du Preez and myself sir.
We took her outside, the grave was about 60 metres from the house's verandah.  Once she was outside, just beyond the verandah, I rendered her unconscious with a heavy blow.
Using a wooden riot baton, police riot baton.
Police baton, all right.  Did you then carry her?
She was immediately unconscious and Du Preez and I then carried her to the grave that was dug in amongst the trees.
Did you take her clothes off?
We then placed Ms Ndwandwe in the grave, half way, sort of half way in.  I then fired a single shot into her head.
From here, she was dead.  We then undressed her.
For clothing and identification purposes.  Clothing could be identified at a later stage.
Did you then place her in the bottom of the grave?
We then placed her in the bottom of the grave and began to fill it in.
First put in a layer of some white lime, some building type lime.
That takes away any smell through the soil for wild animals or for smelling purposes.
Before you placed that over the body, did you also place some plastic bags or agricultural bags over the body?
Mr Chairman, that was done slightly at a later stage.
All right, please continue.  You then started filling in, is that what you are saying?
Yes, there was first the lime and then filled up and then some rubbish bags were placed in on top.
The bags were there should anybody have a look or see anything indentations in that area, one would presume it was a little bit of a dump there Mr Chairman.
Yes, and would then hopefully stop digging?
You were also involved in the matter of Cele?
Which was very, as the Honourable Chairman has pointed out, a very similar situation to the present one, the one of Ndwandwe?
When you say refuse bags, does it include also refuse that was placed somewhere as a layer over the grave?
I can't recall that explicitly, but there would have been some refuse in the bag, I would imagine sir.

When the - after the Promotion of National Unity and Reconciliation Act was passed, you decided to apply for amnesty and is it correct that you did afford your cooperation to the Investigation Unit of the TRC in order to assist them inter alia in pointing out the place, the spot, where she was buried?  I am referring to bundle 4 Mr Chairman?

And there is in bundle 4, at page 452, there is a diagram indicating the direction of the travel of the projectile which killed Ms Ndwandwe in the right hand top corner and the right hand bottom corner?
Would that accord with your recollection of how you fired the shot into her head?
After you had completed that, and the grave had been filled in, what did you then do?
Myself and Du Preez returned to the house sir.
Am I correct in assuming then that you did not, you were not part of the decision makers in regard to this incident?
You followed orders, but you agreed with the contents of the orders?
For reasons which you already told the Committee?
Did you know Mr Labuschagne and Mr Verwey?
And you noticed them there that day, questioning Ms Ndwandwe?
Were they present at the time when she was murdered?
Mr Wasserman, you were also involved in the elimination of Mr Pumeso Nxiweni, is that correct?
And if I understand correctly, you arrived on the afternoon of the 5th of November 1988, with Taylor at the safe house at Verulam?
Where you discovered Nxiweni being held by Botha, Van der Westhuizen and Du Preez?
Will you please tell the Committee what transpired after you had arrived?
At a later stage, I didn't have any questions to ask Mr Nxiweni.  Later on myself, Mr Botha and Mr Du Preez left for the Allan Taylor residence.
Did Du Preez tell you to come along?
And what did, is it correct that you lifted a DLB at the Allan Taylor residence?
Was this DLB, let me rather approach this differently, did you know Nxiweni before that day?
Did you know of activities allegedly participated by him in, in which he participated?
Yes.  We heard of an Allan Taylor unit.  Can you tell the Committee as far as you know, what names you can connect to what you referred to as the Allan Taylor unit?

Mr Chairman, there is some confusion here about the Allan Taylor unit.  An awful lot of MK, military MK activity was emanating from Allan Taylor unit.  I am unable to always specifically state who was in which unit and where, but Pumeso Nxiweni was a prevalent Commander of Allan Taylor.
Yes.  And is it your experience also that some of the members of units, were active in more than one unit at any one time?
Mr Chairman, it is the medical residential quarters for the University of Natal.  It is like a hostel.
And I presume it would change from year to year, the people staying there?
Yes, that would be correct sir.
So you would have a constant turn over of people there?
You were about to tell us that you went with Botha to the Allan Taylor residence, and who else?
Du Preez, all right, and we know that you lifted, well, what did you find there, perhaps you should tell us in your own words?

We went into a store room and found a metal trunk, which we were familiar with, it was the kind of trunk that we were familiar with when it came to DLB's and we opened it and found some explosives inside that trunk.
All right.  Do you know what happened to those explosives which, to the contents of that DLB later?
Mr Chairman, they were in the control of Mr Botha, I don't know what happened with them after that.
Yes.  When you went back, or did you go back to the safe house at Verulam?
What did you find when you arrived there?
Mr Taylor had already commenced to dig a grave outside.
Did he commence to dig the grave, or had he dug the grave?
It was almost dug Mr Chairman.
He was still, he was at the safe house Mr Chairman.
At the safe house, or in the safe house?
In the safe house Mr Chairman.
If I recall correctly, Mr Van der Westhuizen was still there Mr Chairman.
All right, so what happened thereafter?
Mr Taylor sent Van der Westhuizen and Botha away.
All right, and you, Du Preez and Taylor remained behind?
Du Preez and I then led Mr Nxiweni out.
Taylor said yes, we must eliminate Mr Nxiweni.
All right, he gave you the order?
And you say you and Du Preez then led Mr Nxiweni out,yes?
To a point close to the grave.
Mr Du Preez then shot him a single shot in the head.
Was Pumeso not rendered unconscious as had been the case with Ndwandwe?
Not on this occasion at all, no, he was not.
Was Pumeso standing, sitting or laying when Du Preez shot him?
And where on his body, was he shot?
He was shot on the side of his head Mr Chairman.
Which side?  If you can't remember,just say so.
But I can see on the papers, if you show me the paper, I can remember it.  I don't know if it was on the left temple or the right temple.
But he was shot in the temple?
Did you take his clothes off?
Yes, we did, we took off his clothes.
Did you also put lime over the body there?
I don't recall refuse bags Mr Chairman.
Was this during the day or the night?
Night time, could you see what was transpiring?
Yes Mr Chairman, it was with night vision, night eyes, it was fine.
Yes.  Was Mr Pumeso blindfolded when he was led out of the house?
Was the weapon silenced or not?
It was a silenced weapon Mr Chairman.
What happened to the clothes both of Ndwandwe as well as that of Pumeso?
We burnt the clothes on both occasions Mr Chairman.
Both occasions?  Mr Wasserman, you heard the evidence as to why Mr Pumeso was killed, why it was thought necessary to eliminate him.  Do you agree with that evidence?
Mr Chairman, I concur with the evidence given to the Committee thus far.
Were you also aware of the information regarding Mr Nxiweni, which was received from Ms Ndwandwe?
And were you convinced of the truth of what it was alleged that he was involved with as far as MK operations were concerned, in Natal?
Now, going over to the incident of the kwaMashu unit, were you involved in that incident as well?
Can you please inform the Committee what your participation and role was?

Mr Chairman, my activities concur with that, with the evidence given by Mr Botha.  The use of informer there, the capture of the members of the unit on the Avoca Bridge and the transporting thereof, to the safe house.
Were you involved with those informers who penetrated and gained their confidence?
Who was the one who was involved, whose informers were they?
I think Mr Botha was the handler,  I think.
I see.  All right, the fact is that there was an arrest made for want of a better word, at the Avoca Bridge?
Did you have knowledge of a report that they were under way to blow up the railway line at Phoenix?
Railway station, all right, and what happened with them, after they were arrested?
They were taken through to the safe house at Verulam Mr Chairman.
What transpired there Mr Wasserman?  First of all, were they found in possession of anything?
Mr Chairman, on their arrest they had limpet mines with them.
Limpet mines.  Can you remember how many?
How many people did you arrest there?
Were they Mr Ndlovu, Mr Vilakazi and Mr Mtshali?
I didn't know them personally, I knew of them Mr Chairman.
Did you know of their activities?
And that it was alleged that they played a significant role in MK terror operations in Port Natal?
So, at the safe house at Verulam, anything that happened there?
Mr Chairman, we spoke to them, separated them and spoke to them.
I don't recall which of the three I assaulted Mr Chairman.
I spoke to all three on occasions Mr Chairman.
Could you have assaulted all three of them?
What was the purpose of assaulting them?

Mr Chairman, we had information they were on their way to go and do a military operation and I wanted a little bit more facts, very quickly, so I beat them just to make sure that I was going to get what I needed, in time, Mr Chairman.
I would have slapped and punched Mr Chairman.
And with my fists Mr Chairman.
Where on the body of these persons?
It would have been to the face, the ears, the chest Mr Chairperson.
And were they punched in the face as well?
Did they give an explanation about the limpet mines which you found in their possession?
Well, I was informed that they were to be used on that evening's military operation Mr Chairman.
Yes, but in your interrogation, did the kwaMashu 3 give an explanation of their possession of the three limpet mines, that you can remember?
Mr Chairman, not specifically to me was it made, however, I recall being informed that the military weaponry had come from Nxiweni.
Did anybody say that they had been left with them, and they were going to throw them away?
Not to me Mr Chairman, I did hear that later though sir.
All right, so what transpired thereafter?
After that, Mr Taylor arrived at the safe house Mr Chairman.
Could you just speak up a little bit Mr Wasserman, I find it extremely difficult to hear you.
Mr Taylor arrived at the safe house Mr Chairman.
These persons, this unit, was to be taken out to the scene where they were going to do their military activity.
And eliminated at the scene and it was to look as though they had had a mishap in the handling of their own explosives.
Yes, and is that what happened?
That is what happened Mr Chairman.
Did you go out to the scene?
Mr Botha, myself and Mr Du Preez.

All right, Mr Botha gave evidence to say that Taylor remained in the car with these three persons.  I am sorry, just bear a moment with me Mr Chairman.
	I repeat, is it correct that when you arrived there, Mr Taylor remained in the car with the three persons?
What did you go and do and where did you go?
Went to a point on the railway line not too far from Phoenix railway station Mr Chairman.
Du Preez, myself and Botha each had a member of this unit under our control.
You escorted them to this point?
We escorted them to the point on the railway line Mr Chairman.
Well, at this point, each one of us had control of a member of the unit.
Which one did you have control of or don't you remember?
At a sign from Mr Botha, we each shot the one that we were responsible for, once in the head Mr Chairman.
Just how did this happen?  First of all, was it during the day or at night?
No, it was dark, it was night time Mr Chairman.
Dark?  Were they standing up when they were shot?
No, they were on haunches Mr Chairman.
Did someone or all of you, instruct them to sit down?
I just said merely, you know, sit down Mr Chairman, I didn't tell them to do anything.
Was it light enough so that you could see around you?
And you say there was a sign by Botha?
There was a nodding of the head Mr Chairman.
Yes, and you then said that they were all shot, all three of them, with a single shot?
Initially all shot with a single shot, with I had a Scorpion with a silencer on Mr Chairman.
And the others, did they use firearms with or without silencers?
And after you had shot, the three of you had shot one shot into the heads of the victims, what happened then?
Mr Chairman, then they were placed upon...
First of all, did you fire only one shot into the heads?
Oh no, Mr Chairman, I fired a second shot into my victim.
They also did, to my recollection.
To your recollection?  All right, they were then placed you said, just continue?
They were then placed on top of an explosive device, their explosive devices that they had when we arrested them that evening.
What part of their bodies were placed on the explosive device, on the limpet mines?
And what was the purpose of that?
The explosion would render their identities, make them unidentifiable Mr Chairman.
Yes, and the fact that they were shot in the head?
Who prepared the limpet mines for the explosion?
It was done by Mr Du Preez sir.
All right, and did you then leave?
And did you hear the report of the limpet mines detonating?
Did you take part at all in their interrogation or should I rather ask this, was your interrogation of these three directed at attempting to persuade them to become informers on this occasion?
Mr Chairman, I had no, I never ever thought that they would even think about it.
Sorry, just before you proceed, did you not say that you didn't know any one of them personally?
I didn't know any one of them personally, no.
You simply knew of activities in which they were involved?
So why did you think that they would not be prepared to become informers?
I wasn't going to try and turn them Mr Chairman, it wasn't my area of responsibility in the first place.
If I heard you correctly, you were saying that you never, ever thought that they would become informers?
In my brief association with the parties involved, there was no time Mr Chairman, to make an assessment on that.
Was there no time, or was it not the objective?
It certainly wasn't my objective Mr Chairman, I don't know about other members.
You never considered that, that is really what it comes to?
So you cannot say that you never, ever thought that they would become informers?
Well, on that point, what was your experience about more than one person being together and being able to be convinced to become informers?  Was that easier or more difficult?

No, that is exactly the difficult starting point Mr Chairman.  Should three persons be captured together, one will find that it is most difficult to try and turn or make informers of persons in that situation.
Sorry, why didn't you charge them?   Why were they not charged if they were found with the limpet mines?
I am unable to, the decision wouldn't have been mine, and I am unable to pass comment on that Mr Chairman.
Yes.  Apart from the evidence which you gave regarding political situation and the political objectives relating to this incident, did you also hear the evidence of Mr Botha?
And do you also make common cause with what they stated in that regard?

Thank you Mr Chairman.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR VISSER

Thank you Mr Chairman, I have no questions.
NO CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MR NOLTE

Thank you, Prior on behalf of the Amnesty Committee, Evidence Leader, and also standing in for Mr Ngubane, on behalf of the victims.
	Mr Chairman, with your leave I will start with the kwaMashu 3 and then work backwards, those are freshest, if it will not inconvenience anyone.
	Mr Wasserman, what would have happened to you if you had said to Mr Botha, look, I don't want part of this, I don't want to follow this order?
I would imagine my days on the Intelligence gathering unit, might have been numbered.
Do you think he would have sidelined you or had you transferred?
In order to keep your employment with that unit, you decided to carry out this unlawful command?
Mr Chairman, once the command was evident to me, I also accepted it.
So it wasn't just a question of following orders, you made common cause or made common purpose with what was going down there, what was happening?
It wasn't so much the order that moved you, as the activity of your unit?  You were killing operatives at that stage, that was the strategy, is that not so?
It was one finger on the fist Mr Chairman.
Well, you had these people dead to sites, you had them with mini limpet mines, you could have charged them, they would have got at least six, seven, eight years possibly, taken out of circulation.
Would that have been quite a thing to put together, an investigation in the light of the acquittals of Bhila and Nxiweni in Ramlakan?
No, I don't think so Mr Chairman.
It was simply expedient for your purposes or your unit's purposes, to eliminate them as you did?
No Mr Chairman, it was part of the fight against the military fight that was waging at the time, some could be handled by Courts, other actions just didn't seem so.
And as decided by the Durban branch of the Security Police?
As decided by my command structure, at least I know that.
At least I know of my command structure, yes sir.
The evidence of Mr Forster and of Mr Botha, was that primarily the task or the object was always information gathering.  Is that correct?

You have been asked this by a member of the panel.  Can you think of any reason given your experience, background, in the field, why even an attempt was not made to try and turn these, the kwaMashu 3?

Mr Chairman, I don't know if the other parties did try to turn any of these personalities.  In my presence it didn't occur.
	I don't know amongst themselves, if they tried.  But also it gets to the point of when there are three picked up, if one agreed, the other two would be in the way, so  that is the difficulty in this particular instance.
Do you know how they were arrested or picked up, in other words what plan or what legend was created?
No, I was briefed to meet my unit, and we were to effect the capture on the Avoca Bridge Mr Chairman.
Did it appear to you as if they were waiting for people that they knew?  In other words a rendezvous?
So they expected to meet comrades, was that part of the plan?
I don't know what they were told, whether it was to be comrades or finances or somebody, but they were to meet somebody.
And those informers, were they present on that occasion, or not?
And you said those informers were handled by Mr Botha?
I think that is correct Mr Chairman.
You don't know if they are the same people in the Ndwandwe matter?
I don't know that Mr Chairman.
You say you had a Scorpion pistol, who issued you that weapon?
It was the ANC's weapon Mr Chairman.
Where did you, where did you obtain it from?
I obtained it from an ANC DLB that was lifted.
Was that the one at Allan Taylor as you say?
No Mr Chairman.  We lifted hundreds of DLB's, I can't recall which one this one came from.
Did you simply keep those weapons under your control, that is the Security Branch, Durban, to use whenever you felt like it?
So those weapons would not necessarily have been handed in through the official channels?
And the other persons, Botha and Du Preez, what were they armed with, similar weapons?
If we can just go now to Pumeso Nxiweni.  This Allan Taylor unit, you say all you can recall is that Nxiweni was the Overall Commander?
Round about this stage, yes Mr Chairman.
You can't remember anybody else that possibly was a member?
Mr Chairman, I would be wrong to just add up names, I can't recall names right now.
If it was suggested to you that the Allan Taylor unit broke up at the time of the trial or the arrest of the accused in the Ramlakan matter and was never regrouped, what would your comment be?
I would doubt that very much Mr Chairman.
Although you don't have any information about specific persons who were actually members during 1987 and 1989?
No Mr Chairman, I can't recall that portion.
And you worked closely with Mr Botha, did you not?
So it was virtually, it would have come to your attention had there been active members, other than Nxiweni involved at Allan Taylor?
No Mr Chairman, there definitely were active members, there definitely were, I just can't recall the names.
During the arrests of the accused involved in the Ramlakan trial, was a DLB also discovered at Allan Taylor?
Mr Chairman, I actually can't recall specifically but there were weapons recovered, yes.
And I understand standard procedure for example a container, that would be dusted for prints?
I mean that is written in the book?
On this occasion, after the arrest of Nxiweni, you discovered a DLB at the Allan Taylor residence, in a storage room?
No, not at all Mr Chairman.

And we have gone through this with the other applicants, there was a golden opportunity to prosecute Nxiweni and have him removed out of circulation for a number of years, on the strength of the ammunition and explosives and that DLB?
Yes, I heard that evidence given.
Can you maybe advance a reason why there was this departure from the normal practice?
No Mr Chairman, I have to concur with the evidence given previously by the other applicants.
Unless the decision was already to eliminate Nxiweni, and not to bother about investigating any charges against him?  That would seem to fit the scenario, would it not?
I am unaware of that particular setup as you are outlining it now Mr Chairman.
It seems to my mind that Nxiweni was unlikely to be a person to be turned, I am talking about 1988?  Would you agree?
Can we then accept that the only reason why Nxiweni was then detained or arrested, was for purposes of his elimination?
I am unable to answer that Mr Chairman, my Commanders would have to answer that.
Well, what was your sense, you worked very close to Botha?  I mean surely he would have discussed with you what the strategy would be, would have been?
Sorry, there is too much noise from down here, I couldn't hear anything.

I will repeat it.  I just get a sense from replies that I have heard today and over the last couple of days, that everyone seemed to just have their own agenda.  Surely Botha would have discussed with you what was to happen with Nxiweni, that there was a plan to have him arrested and once he was arrested or detained or abducted, whatever the position was, whether to prosecute him, to turn him or whatever?
Mr Chairman, when this gentleman was arrested, I wasn't even in this country.
I was away, I was in Swaziland.  So, I wasn't aware of this.
All right.  The weapon you used to kill Mr Nxiweni, what was that?  Was it also a Scorpion?
Mr Du Preez shot him, you were together, acting together?
It was a Scorpion, and he was only shot once?

It seems from the post mortem report at page 510, in bundle 4 Mr Chairman, one sees the entry wound on the left side of the skull, probably just behind the left ear and exiting on the right hand side.
I see that and concur with that Mr Chairman.
Was he shot from very close range?
Was it almost a contact shot or can't you say?
It was very, very close indeed Mr Chairman.
What, a few inches or a few millimetres or a few centimetres?
Was lime also, I think you said that, all right, just one other aspect, you said Taylor had begun or had started to dig the grave for Nxiweni?
That is what he said in his amnesty application.
I don't know what he said in his amnesty application.
Was it unusual that he should have dug the grave?
No, not when you knew Mr Taylor, Mr Chairman, no.
I want to deal with Fila Ndwandwe's incident.  This was a, the foray into Swaziland was a well planned operation, was it not?

Given the evidence we have heard today, General Steyn, et al Mr Botha over the last few days, would I be correct in understanding that the planning was such that the risk of things going wrong, was reduced to a very, very bare minimum?
Yes Mr Chairman, that is right.
And obviously you people didn't want to spend any more time than you had to, in Swaziland, after the abduction of Ms Ndwandwe?
And I would also like to believe that you would have planned the whole operation that you would have been able to return before the border post closed at ten o'clock on the same day?
We had planned that Mr Chairman.
In other words, you left yourself sufficient time to get back to the border post, to exit Swaziland?
It would be dangerous to remain back in Swaziland, particularly if word had got out that she had been abducted by the Security Branch?
Well, it wouldn't have been ideal to be there.

Precisely.  Now, what time did you get to the border fence, that was where obviously you had got through a hole in the fence or whatever, the fence was cut or whatever it was, near Onverwacht.  What time was that approximately?
Half past eight, 9 o'clock Mr Chairman.
That seems to be Colonel Forster's recollection as well.  Now from there to Culel, or to Lavumisa, which is on the Swazi side, how far is that approximately by vehicle?  Less than 50 kilometres?
Would it have taken you more than an hour and a half to leave Onverwacht where you had dropped off Botha and Ndwandwe to get back to Lavumisa, to travel that distance to the border post?

Mr Chairman, it was very, very wet, the road was very muddy, that is why only the vehicle, the 4 x 4 could continue.  To go back on that same broken road, the road was pretty mushed up from merely getting there.
All right, just look at page 443 of bundle 4.  You were in the vicinity where the road that looks like a dirt road, crosses the border, is that correct, the international line?
So would you have driven back to the crossroad with Hluti?
And then you would have turned to the south towards Lavumisa?
Well, that is the road that you are discussing now.
You said you couldn't go along the dirt road, because it was too mushy?
Because of the weather?  So which road did you go, which road did you follow?
We went the other way, heading to Hlangano.
So you went further away from Onverwacht?
Right, you went to Hlangano and then where, did you turn up towards where?
Then up to Hlatikulu, that is all tarred road now sir.  Hlatikulu, and then up towards Manzini and then back the other way.
So even though you had a 4 x 4 vehicle, you didn't want to travel the 30 kilometres to Culel, but went via a ...(indistinct) route?
It is not a ...(indistinct) route Mr Chairman,it is the right way to go.  I did know the area, I was from there.
Did you tell Mr Botha that you were going to take this route back and you wouldn't be able to get back before the border post closed?
We knew once we had done the handover, we were not going to get back in time for the border.
Did you tell him, that is the question?
So he was aware that he wouldn't see you that evening?
You say it was difficult, it would have been difficult to find out where Ms Ndwandwe lived.  Mr Botha's evidence was that you had her address?
We had a couple of her addresses, but you couldn't tell where she would be on Monday night, or which one on Tuesday.
At Onverwacht, did you take part in any interrogation of her?
What was her condition when you saw her at Onverwacht the next morning?
She was relaxed, she was fine Mr Chairman.
I can't recall that, no, no.
Would she have been, surely she would have been restrained in case she tried to escape?
Mr Chairman, at Onverwacht, at the border post?
At the safe house, where she spent the evening with the others?
Mr Chairman, I can't recall if she was handcuffed.
She never complained to you about anything?
She wasn't complaining about her predicament?
She didn't complain to me about her predicament at all Mr Chairman.
Did you travel with her back to Pietermaritzburg, in the same vehicle that is?
I was in the same vehicle, but in the front with Mr Du Preez.
And was she being interrogated in that vehicle or was not much said?
No, they were talking in the back of the vehicle Mr Chairman.
Questions and answers, the vehicle is blocked off.  The driver cannot see, the front crew cannot see into the back Mr Chairman.
So you don't know what occurred in the back there, apart from that you heard a discussion of sorts?
And you can't tell us whether she gave any important information up or not, over that period?
I was briefed on that when we got to the Maritzburg farm.
At Pietermaritzburg, how long did she spend at that safe house, sorry, on the farm?
She was there all the time Mr Chairman.
Until what time, what time was she taken out, was it in the early evening to be killed?
It was already dark Mr Chairman, I would say 19H00, 20H00.
And at that safe house, were you there most of the day?
I was, most of the day, yes.
Well, who interrogated her?  Do you know?
Mr Botha Mr Chairman, and Mr Steyn, Mr Chairman.
I looked in the room, Mr Chairman, yes, I saw them talking with her.
From time to time, you would pop in?
That is exactly right Mr Chairman.
To hear how things were going, and to listen.
Did you also pop in from time to time when Mr Labuschagne and Mr Verwey were interrogating her?
This must have been an intense interrogation?  I mean you had a dangerous terrorist in your custody?
What are you trying to say Mr Chairman?
Just answer the question, was it an intense interrogation?
By the evening stage, I think it was casual to my mind, Mr Chairman.
She had been interrogated virtually the whole of that day?
Well Mr Chairman, if that is an intensive interrogation to your mind, then that is how it is.
And the decision had already been made at Onverwacht to eliminate her?  You have heard that evidence?
So what were you trying to, what were you trying to get out of her?  Information I would imagine?
Well, I would imagine information Mr Chairman.
And she wasn't giving the information, is that correct, because it took so long.  You said the interrogation lasted until the virtually the evening?
I never had any interrogation to do with her Mr Chairman.
Wasn't the case that she was a very hard nut to crack?
And she remained defiant to the bitter end?
And she refused to cooperate with the Security Branch?
In my presence, that is correct, yes.
And I should imagine there was no difference, her being a female and being treated in a certain way, as Nxiweni was treated being a male person, he was punched and slapped on his body?
She wasn't punched or slapped on her body.
Why not, what was the difference?
Because she was a female, are you saying that there was some sense of chivalry shown to her?
No, I am trying to find out Mr Wasserman, because we can't, you are not prepared to volunteer anything.
Mr Chairman, she was not assaulted at all.
She must have known at some stage, she was going to be  executed, would you agree?
I am unable to say so Mr Chairman.
Well, when you led her out of the house, was she blindfolded?
She was blindfolded and believed she was going to be collected and moved to another safe house.
Is that what you told her?
She accepted that, she had no choice.
And then you clubbed her on the head from behind?

Did you strike her on the, can you maybe just tell us, because the post mortem showed a fracture and I just want to clarify that.  Did you hit her on the back of the head, on the jaw or can't you remember?
Mr Chairman, no, it was on the right hand side of her head.
Could my learned friend point the fracture out to us Mr Chairman.

If my learned friend looks at page 452 on the right hand side, the diagram of the skull, there is reference to fracture lines, arrows.  But in any event, I am not going to proceed with that, you indicated that the blow was of sufficient force to render her unconscious?
And it was just the one blow that you administered?
And was she standing up when you administered that blow?
And obviously she didn't know that you were going to strike her at the time that you administered that blow?
You then placed her in the grave, is that right?
And well, did you lay her down?  In what position did you place her before you shot her?
Mr Chairman, she was virtually lying down in the grave, but in a slightly seated up position.
I am coming to that, and you know why, you have seen the diagram of the bullet wound.
She was shot from the top of her head with the exit coming out at the roof of her mouth?  That has been shown to you?
Would you agree with that being the position?
And after you shot her, you then stripped the body, is that correct?

Thank you Mr Chairman, I have no further questions.

	The family are concerned that possibly in their endeavours to find Nxiweni, shortly after the acquittal in the Ramlakan case, that possibly Mfeti was mistaken for Nxiweni, and he was abducted and dealt with.  Are you able in any way, to give up any information that may assist the families?
Mr Chairman, I don't even know that name.  I have never even heard that name.

You say that after you shot Portia Ndwandwe as well as Pumeso Nxiweni, you covered the body with lime.  Where did you get this lime?
It would have been bought at one or so, hardware store.  I can't recall where it was bought Mr Chairman.
Mr Chairman, no, I don't know why was it bought.
It would have been purchased to cover the body, to stop an odour coming through the soil.
But from your evidence it seems that the lime was already there when you shot and killed these people?  Did you have lime stocked in that safe house for these kinds of actions?
No Mr Chairman, I was given the lime Mr Chairman.
I was given the lime Mr Chairman, by Mr Taylor.
When did he get this lime?
I don't know when he got the lime Mr Chairman.
So in other words, you don't know where this lime came from?
I don't know when he got it or where he got it from Mr Chairman.

Another thing which I want to clarify in my mind, is how many people in the Durban Security Branch belonged to the, I will call it the inner circle, the few people who were responsible for these killings as far as you know?
Mr Chairman, as far as I know, it would only be the applicants that are before the Committee.
Why were you particularly chosen for this type of work, what is it that you had done, were you given any training for killing or what by the Security Branch?
Mr Chairman, no, I am as military trained as anybody else and I was just in the Umkhonto weSizwe section.
The reason I am asking you is because you say that you were not in the country when Mr Nxiweni was arrested.
On that occasion I was debriefing informers in Swaziland Mr Chairman.
But why would you be the one to be chosen to kill him, to be given the orders that you must kill him?
I have no idea on how to even answer that Mr Chairman.
Before my colleague asks questions, did Mr Taylor give you this lime when he told you to eliminate, did he say well, take them outside, eliminate them and sprinkle lime on them?
He knew of the lime, these occasions here, he actually handed me the packet of lime.
Did he tell you what to do with it?
Yes Mr Chairman, he told me to spread it.
On top of the bodies, after you undressed them?

I wanted to ask this same question, but just from a different angle, clearly the lime wasn't purchased specifically for these events, because the lime was there, it was evening, decisions were made at night.  You have no knowledge of anyone going out to buy it specifically for the burying of specific victims that your applications relate to?
No Mr Chairman, I am not aware of that.
And the lime was not only available in Pietermaritzburg near Elandskop, it was also available on other farms?
It was used on the other farm as well Mr Chairman.
You were involved on more than one occasion, with spreading lime?
Yes Mr Chairman, they are in the application.
Yes.  And did you form any opinion as to the availability of the lime?
You can't tell us whether you think even at this stage, whether lime was kept for such occasions or whether it was specifically bought?
No Mr Chairman, I never ever saw lime laying around, I was just handed it on the occasion.  I never saw packets of lime.
And you have no idea where Taylor got the lime from?
How big were the packets that you were given?  You weren't given a bag of lime, you were given a small packet, not a 50 kg pocket?
No Mr Chairman, a small packet which you would tear the top off and sprinkle.
Yes, but was it pre-packed by the distributor, the manufacturer or whoever would have distributed it?
Yes Mr Chairman.  It was in, it looked like the commercial packaging.

The other issue that I just want to further pursue is, you gave evidence last week about the elimination of Bhila and your simply being present at the time, that at some later stage you became aware that he was to be eliminated?  Is that correct?
Mr Taylor told me at a later stage, yes.

In this, it really relates to the same question, a group of people involved, I find it extremely difficult to look at the applicants as you have referred to them, as the only people within the so-called inner circle for want of a better word, that you never discussed these incidents with each other, that you wouldn't ask questions, even as to where was the person killed, how was he killed, was he buried or not, where was he buried.  You heard the evidence, and this is the line of evidence, that you never spoke of it?

Mr Chairman, that is correct.  In this kind of job, nobody ever would speak out, it would stay where it was, that is where it was.  There was a code of ethics that one wouldn't ask and one wouldn't say.
Not even amongst co-perpetrators, people planning together, deciding together to kill a person?  You wouldn't ask questions of each other?
No Mr Chairman, if that portion was yours to do, then that was done, and it was left at that Mr Chairman.  It was left at that.

Was there ever such an instruction not to ask questions, not to talk?  Did that code of ethic if one could call it such, simply develop out of the blue, did it just dawn upon you or was it agreed, did Taylor or someone tell you listen, no one asks questions, no one speaks?

Mr Chairman, I am unable if there was a person specifically there, but it was very evident amongst us all that such a code was there, but nobody specifically ever told me that is how it is.
	It just comes in the Special Branch type of activity.
So, as far as Port Natal is concerned, your involvement with Bhila, was that an induction in a sense, an initiation with the group or not so?
When did you become aware of this code of ethics of not speaking and not asking and not reporting?
I already knew of that in my previous service Mr Chairman.
In the Rhodesian setup Mr Chairman.
So you had similar experiences there, is that what you are telling us?
No, not at all Mr Chairman, but in war and in operations, one learns that this ethic is there.
Not even to discuss with people who went out on the same mission with you?
Mr Chairman, the details weren't discussed, the result would have been.
May I add something Mr Chairman.  May I add on the question of the lime.
Well, I think we were going to talk about the same thing, page 444?
You haven't been told yet, when the body was exhumed, a yellow plastic bag, dolomite agricultural lime, 10 kg was around both feet.  Would that be about the size of the bags that you were given?
That is the size Mr Chairman.
